2019 DYAL WATER TREATMENT PLANT-CITY OF COCOA

RISK MANAGEMENT PROGRAM RE-SUBMITTAL

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



1.    EXECUTIVE SUMMARY INTRODUCTION 68.155 

The City of Cocoa Utilities Department operates the City of Cocoa's Claude H. Dyal (Dyal) Water Treatment Plant at 28400 E. SR 520, Christmas, Orange County, Florida.  This plant is one of two water plants operated by the City.  Only the Dyal water plant has quantities of a regulated hazardous chemical, chlorine, above the EPA threshold.  The City has a unified Risk Management Program which applies to each plant.  Only the Dyal Water Treatment Plant operations and policies are presented in this plan.



1.1.    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION/EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES (A)

The City of Cocoa Water Treatment Plant accidental release prevention policy involves a unified approach that integrates technologies, procedures and management practices.  The plant's prevention program complies with all applicable procedures of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program (RMP) 40 CFR-68 Prevention Program under the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990.



1.2.    MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS (A) (1)

The City of Cocoa has a management system in place which is led by the City Manager.  The City Utilities Director oversees the implementation and on-going use of the RMP elements.  The Dyal Water Treatment Plant Superintendent oversees the daily operation.  An organizational chart defining the lines of authority and responsible staff is included in the plant's RMP Process Safety Information.  The Dyal management and employees use this program, along with other City-wide and plant-specific policies.  This eliminates and/or reduces the likelihood of a hazardous chemical release at the plant. 



1.3.    PREVENTION PROGRAM LEVEL 3 (A) (2)

The City of Cocoa maintains policies, procedures and systems as part of their prevention program.  These are applied to each treatment plant and specifically the Dyal Water Treatment Plant.  The prog

ram addresses each of the EPA Prevention Program Level 3-listed elements as well as related RMP elements needed to implement the program.  The Dyal plant follows the like elements of the OSHA PSM program.  The City is exempt from compliance with OSHA.  The policies and procedures are maintained by the Water Treatment Plant Document Management System (DMS).



2.    STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE HANDLED AT CITY OF COCOA, FLORIDA DYAL WTP SITE (B)  



The City of Cocoa Dyal Water Treatment Plant employs 53 full-time employees engaged in water treatment plant and field operations.  Elemental Chlorine is used as part of the disinfection treatment process.

             

2.1.    SITE DESCRIPTION (B) (1)    

The site is owned and operated by The City of Cocoa and managed by its Utilities Department.  The site is located at 28400 E. SR 520, Christmas, Orange County, Florida.  The 62-acre site is located in an area bordered by SR 250 on the east, South Taylor Creek Rd on the west and private property on the north.

The Dyal Chlorination system includes two separate rooms.  One for chlorine storage and feeding chlorine from the ton containers.  Chlorine under vacuum is feed to the second control room where the chlorine is metered through chlorinator units and fed to the various remote injections points.   

The boundaries of the chlorine system subject to the RMP regulations:  the Bulk Chlorine Storage and feed systems associated, vent makeup, exhaust systems, chlorine scrubber, and chlorine injection cabinets at various injection points.  These are detailed in the Process and Instrument Drawings (P&ID) which are part of Dyal's Process Safety Information (PSI).  All drawings are maintained in the plants RMP Process Safety Information.



2.1.1.    REGULATED SUBSTANCE (b) (2)

Chlorine is the only regulated substance on site which exceeds the EPA 40 CFR-68 rule threshold quantity of 2,500 pounds.  The City of Cocoa chlorine process was installed as part of the process of p

urifying water for public consumption.  It operates under permit from the State of Florida Department of Environmental Protection (FL DEP).  The ton containers of chlorine are received, stored and distributed to water treatment process control systems. 

Chlorine is an EPA and OSHA-listed toxic chemical.  It is an irritant and it is corrosive.  Chlorine is a halogen with the formula Cl2.  It is a chlorinating or oxidizing agent that is not flammable.  It has a 1 ppm OSHA ceiling Permissible Exposure Limit (PEL) and a NFPA health rating of 4, severe; with immediate and delayed health hazards.  Chlorine is not a carcinogen.

The maximum threshold quantity stored on site is 48, one-ton containers.  This equals 96,000 pounds.

3.    GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC STEPS



3.1.    HAZARD ASSESSMENT

A hazard assessment was performed to determine the effects a release would have on the environment and the public. For chlorine, the distance to a set endpoint concentration of the gas would travel must be determined.  In addition, an estimate of the population to public receptors that could be affected by a release of chlorine was determined, and sensitive receptors such as hospitals, schools, and nursing homes were identified.  The hazard assessment considers two release scenarios "worst case" and "alternative case" and also compiles the five-year accident history for the WTP chlorine system.

Two offsite consequence analyses were conducted which include two chlorine release scenarios.  The first is a "worst case release".  The second is a more probable "alternative release scenario".  The first scenario is defined by EPA, which states that "the operator shall assume that the maximum quantity in the largest vessel is released as a gas over 10 minutes" due to an unspecified failure.  The alternative scenario is defined as "more likely to occur than the worst-case scenario".  This scenario was determined by the PHA HazOp team.

Atmospheric dispe

rsion modeling was performed to determine the distance traveled by the chlorine released before its concentration decreases to the "toxic endpoint."  The EPA-specified endpoint for chlorine is 0.0087 mg/l which equals three ppm. The three ppm endpoint is the Emergency Response Planning Guideline Level 2 (ERPG-2).  This is defined by the American Industrial Hygiene Association (AIHA) as the "maximum airborne concentration below which it is believed that nearly all individuals could be exposed for up to one hour without experiencing or developing irreversible or other serious health effects or symptoms which could impair an individual's ability to take protective action."  The residential population within a circle with a radius corresponding to the toxic endpoint distances was defined to estimate the population potentially affected.

Note, items with an ** are redacted per EPA protocol.



3.3.    ALTERNATIVE CASE (C) (2)

The alternative release scenario involves the failure of the regulator of the pressure system or the whip on pipes/valves connected to one of the one-ton containers.  This failure was defined during the recent Process Hazards Analysis.  This failure is equal to creating a 0.03-square inch hole in the wip tube, a pipe, or even the ton container itself.  Modeling using the EPA/RMP Comp and EPA's water guidance demonstra

ted the rate of chlorine release is 200.0 lbs. /minutes for a period of 60 minutes releasing a total of 2,000 pounds of chlorine.  The toxic endpoint distances determined is ** miles containing ** miles and is in the process safety information.  The residential population that would be impacted by this release is **and is recorded in the process safety information.  Receptors in this area were identified.

The City has improved the safety system by installing and emergency shut down valve on each ton container.  Therefore if a leak occurs the chlorine detections alarm system causes the emergency valves to close and the scrubber to come on.  



4.    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM (D)

The City of Cocoa's accidental release prevention program is based on OSHA's PSM program and EPA's RMP Level 3 prevention program.  The PSM/RMP program has been in place and effectively used for many years.  It is part of the plants operating culture.  There are two parts to the program.  The first is the general overall water division wide program and second is the Dyal site-specific program.  The second is the chlorine-specific actions within the site program.  This is coordinated with the Orange County Fire/Rescue Department (including the Haz Mat Team) and the Regional LEPC.



4.1.    GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM (D) (1)

Plant-wide, many elements of the prevention program are used for all operations.  An overview of the generally written programs is listed below:



4.1.1.    Facility Design

The chlorine storage area is housed in a closed building.  Its doors are closed and locked requiring an entry key.  The plant and support equipment of the chlorine storage building and adjacent control room meet and exceed design code standards and good engineering practices.  The storage and control building rooms are equipped with forced ventilation systems.  There is a chlorine area monitor inside the storage room.  If chlorine is detected in the storage room, the monitor

alarms, shuts down each ton container's emergency shutdown valves and the forced air ventilation system.  It also starts the building chlorine vent fume scrubber and the scrubber is capable of neutralizing over 2,000 pounds of chlorine.  The control room also has a chlorine monitor.  Both monitors alarm in their local area as well as in the water plant control room. 



4.1.2.    Equipment Design

There are two types of chlorine pipe systems, high pressure and low (vacuum) pressure.  The high pressure chlorine piping system is made of chlorine compatible (not corroded by chlorine) steel pipes, copper tubes or non-metallic materials.  Ton containers are rated to 500 psig.  The maximum pressure of the chlorine in the high pressure system is 150 psig giving a 3-to-1 safety factor.  There are two sets of six ton containers on each high pressure line.  An emergency shutdown valve (ESV) is connected directly to the ton container top angle valve.  All of the ESVs will close if a chorine monitor detects one ppm of chlorine in this room  That alarm signal also starts the chlorine vent scrubber.  Both the ESVs and vent scrubber can be operated manually.  The ESV discharges to an angle valve and flexible whip.  Each whip leads to a header which feeds into an automatic vacuum pressure regulator which switches chlorine from the empty line to the standby line.  This one bank is in service and the other is on standby.  Chlorine from the high pressure system feeds the low pressure system.  The chlorine in the high pressure system can only reach 140 psig if the temperature of the tons reaches 100 degrees Fahrenheit.  This provides a large safety factor.  

The low pressure system operates under a vacuum pressure of 13 inches or more of mercury.  There is a pressure relief valve which vents if the pressure in the line goes above atmospheric pressure.  All the pipe, tubes, and equipment are also chlorine compatible.  The system piping is PVC.  It has glass and other material that are not

affected by chlorine under vacuum.

There is a chlorine monitor which detects the presence of chlorine in the ton storage area and a second monitor in the chlorine control room. 



4.1.3.    Equipment Design

The chlorine system design is based on the Chlorine Institute's criteria.  Dyal maintains detailed process safety information on each of its operations.  This includes a Safety Data Sheet for each chemical, Maintenance and Operating Procedures, etc.  



4.1.4.    Mechanical Integrity 

Maintenance and preventive maintenance are used for all equipment.  The chlorine system has a detailed equipment list which covers inspection, testing and repair.  Dyal's mechanical integrity program is used to ensure that the chlorination system operates safely. 

The document maintenance system is an integral to the management of change for the chlorination system. 

 

4.1.5.    Training Program

Training is the backbone of employee knowledge, job operations and is ongoing for the plant staff.  Employee training in operations and maintenance emphasizes awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of all chemicals used.  RMP refresher training as well as all other related operating procedures is conducted annually.



4.1.6.    Incident Investigations 

The City conducts an accident and near-miss incident to ensure we learn from each event as well as correct the causes of the incident.  This applies to all operations of the water treatment plant.



4.1.7.    Employees

Employees participate in all aspects of the plant as listed below under emergency response. 

Safe work practices are used throughout the facility including:  1) Hot Work Permits, 2) Lockout/Tagout Permits, 3) Vessel Entry Permits, 4) Site Security, and 5) Breaking Into Chemical Lines. 

Contractors must meet The City of Cocoa's high safety and technical standards as part of selection and ongoing evaluations.  City of Cocoa demands contractor training and work procedures meet its safety standards. 



4.2.    CHLORINE SPECI

FIC RESPONSE PROGRAM (D) (2)



4.2.1.    Chlorine-Specific Operating Safety Information

Chemical-specific PSI includes the policies and procedures listed above and those used in the chlorine program.  



4.2.2.    Specific procedures for the management of the chlorine process 

The procedures include completion of a Management of Change form and also a Pre-startup Safety Review prior to startup of the modified chlorine system.   

Specific emergency response procedures for chlorine releases are outlined below under both operating procedures and in the emergency response procedures.  See the Emergency Response Program book. 

Specific training in the properties, hazards, handling requirements, and leak repair for chlorination system is conducted annually. 

Finally, the details of both the facility and equipment design are kept in the Process Safety Information and are key to the safe operations of the chlorination system.



5.    FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY (E)

The plant has been chlorine reportable release free since 1992 to the present, 27 years

.

6.    EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM (F)

Emergency response procedures are contained in the Plant Emergency Response Policies which are coordinated with the Orange County Contingency Plan (Emergency Response Plan).  The plan includes an emergency response "decision tree" and a notification plan.  Dyal also has site-specific emergency actions defined in the plants operating procedures.  Emergency response drills and evacuation drills are conducted annually by the operating department.  Emergency operation and response procedures are also reviewed annually.

The emergency response program (contingency plan) is coordinated (reviewed by) with the Dyal Safety Committee.  Dyal coordinates with local Orange County Emergency Response Planning Committee (LEPC) and the Orange County HazMat Team.  All are located in Orange County, Florida.  Copies of the program are given to key local agencies including: fire, medical, rescue, management, a

nd police departments.  Besides the specific emergency response program, key elements of the prevention programs are incorporated in the operating culture of Dyal.

The Contingency Plan procedures detail the actions and responses to chlorine spills (releases).  The plan includes training of all staff. The primary response team includes the Orange County Fire and Rescue, and county Haz Mat Teams.  All of these respond to any severe chlorine leak situation.  Actions include catastrophic, severe, and moderate leaks.  A Chlorine "B" Leak Repair Kit for ton containers is maintained at the chlorine storage area to aid in stopping leaks.  Public notification is facilitated through the County Fire and Sheriff's Office, which has an automated emergency dialing message system for public notification.  The plant's emergency information also lists the phone number of local residents to warn in an emergency.



7.    PERSONNEL (F) (1)

Personnel are the key resource of the City of Cocoa's prevention program.  City employees make up the operators and emergency operations first responders.  Operators are trained to the Operations Level per 40 CFR 68.  The City of Cocoa fosters a high level of involvement in every aspect of the chlorine system operations including participation in:

?    PSM/RMP safety teams, 

?    Development of the operation procedures, 

?    Hazard evaluations, 

?    On-going training of the operators and other involved staff, and

?    Process Hazards Analysis (PHA) review meetings.



8.    CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY (G)

Changes to improve safety (recommended actions) are identified in the internal safety audit, the HazOp, Safety training, plant tours, internal audits and audits by regulator of the FL Department of Emergency Management of the RMP program.  The State Fire Marshal ensures that the plant meets requirements of the RMP Program.  

The plant recently installed an emergency shutdown valve (ESV) on each ton container in use.  This safety upgrade was based on a request

from the State Fire Marshall.  These ESVs limit the quantity of a release to that of a single ton container.  An audit was conducted to review the RMP program.  The key safety action items were completed and documented in Section 6 of that Audit Report.  Dyal's staff continually reviews implemented operating procedures for potential safety improvements for all of its operations.  Currently, the City of Cocoa Dyal plant management team and process safety team are reviewing replacing the existing gaseous chlorine system.  Sodium hypochlorite (Bleach) would be used in place of gaseous chlorine. This will make the system even safer and eliminate a release of chlorine.  This project is slated to be completed in 2020.

The City of Cocoa Dyal Water Treatment Plant has completed the EPA-required Vulnerability Assessment (VA).  Recommendations from the VA report improved site security and safety overall including that of the chlorine system.
